item.title: The secret of the Consumer Cooperative
item.description:
We often say that the key to a Consumer Cooperative's success is for its members to be Workers' Cooperatives. Otherwise, the profits for individual members will be less than the cost of participating, and once the voluntarism phase has passed, managerialism (a bureaucracy of managers) will take over.

This isn't entirely true, even if it's the ideal. The model also works when the co-op's partners are companies with clear service objectives. An example from Italy with decades of positive results.

"Fifty years of Cirfood. From the first workers' cafeteria to national excellence: "Healthy and affordable food." Over 98 million meals served throughout Italy by 2024, with nearly 13,000 employees. The cooperative, based in Reggio Emilia, continues to be a driving force of development and social well-being."

item.title: Mental Health, Depression, and Young People in France
item.description:
"In general, the prevalence of depression increases with adulthood. Thus, 17% of 15- to 17-year-olds suffer from this illness, 27% of those aged 18 to 21, 28% of those aged 22 to 25, and 23% of those aged 26 to 29.

Furthermore, the social roots of this malaise are highlighted. Among young people in highly precarious situations, 47% suffer from depression, compared to 16% of 15- to 29-year-olds without financial hardship. Furthermore, 32% of those who consider themselves to have experienced difficult economic circumstances in childhood report depression. In contrast, depression affects 18% of young people who consider themselves to have grown up in favorable economic conditions.

Furthermore, depression affects 35% of those who lived in an unstable family environment, compared to 15% of those who say they grew up in a healthy family environment.

Furthermore, the study notes differences between urban and rural youth. Twenty-seven percent of urban youth suffer from depression, 7 percentage points more than rural youth (20%). Sixty-four percent of young people living in metropolitan areas report feeling sad, depressed, or hopeless in the past two weeks, compared to 59% in suburban areas and 54% in rural areas.

item.title: The Zeitgeist that leads to authoritarianism
item.description:
The violent exchanges of tension between the major parties in the US are leading to a more authoritarian state, regardless of who governs.

"If we are convinced that political violence comes only from one side of the divide, then the temptation toward punitive authoritarianism is overwhelming. "They" are evil and violent, and "they" must be crushed.

However, if we accurately understand that the United States has an immense problem with violent extremism on both ideological sides—even if, at any given time, one side is worse than the other—then the solution lies in reconciliation, not domination. In fact, it is the will to dominate that exacerbates the crisis and radicalizes our opponents.

item.title: Indonesia and the cooperative revitalization of the countryside
item.description:
The Indonesian government has unveiled a plan to encourage the creation of an Agri-Food Cooperative in every county or village, up to 80,000 spread across the vast country.

"With villages plagued by poverty and lack of opportunities, the goal is to use the cooperative model to boost economic participation. However, this ambitious project will require strong local governance, supported by integrated digital technology, with data collected from 20,000 self-sufficient villages by the Ministry of Village, Disadvantaged Areas Development, and Transmigration."

The project is being implemented in four phases, organized by geographic area: Yogyakarta and Central Java, with a target of 2,680 cooperatives; Riau Islands, North Sumatra, Aceh, West Java, Lampung, and South Sumatra, with a target of 5,800 cooperatives; Jakarta, Banten, and South Sulawesi, with a target of 2,244 cooperatives; and East Java and Bali, with a target of 5,412 cooperatives.

item.title: The U.S. Senate creates a new type of investment company to facilitate the transition to EOT or Work Cooperative.
item.description:
The proposed measure, called the American Ownership and Resilience Act, would create a new federal program under the Department of Commerce to support businesses' transition to worker ownership.

This would be accomplished through the creation and funding of Ownership Investment Companies (OICs), specialized firms that would use federally guaranteed capital (up to $5 billion annually) to finance the sale of companies to Employee Stock Ownership Plans (ESOPs/EOTs) or Workforce Cooperatives.

item.title: Success stories in the USA
item.description:
The American press is filled with advice, stories from well-known companies, and ESOP and EOT success stories. All with the inevitable triumphalist tone of management books and case studies.

Bloomingkemper's approach is based on two key principles. First, transparency in measuring value. Second, a clear contractual path linking contribution to future reward. From the outset, employment contracts included a formula detailing how profits would be shared with those who contributed to the growth of the business, payable upon sale.

This clarity did more than offer positive potential. It changed employees' mindsets, shares Bloomingkemper. Employees began to see themselves as managers, not just staff. Managers transcended their roles and made smart decisions because their work truly mattered. Sales teams forged lasting relationships with customers, aware that every deal determined their future. Success became something everyone had.

item.title: Robotization in the Agrarian Cooperative
item.description: A livestock cooperative in the Czech Republic is robotizing the feeding of stabled cattle due to a lack of workers. Depopulation and aging are pushing the Agricultural Cooperative toward almost total robotization, while properties are abandoned, closed, or sold, increasing the concentration of land and farms. However, there is an alternative that does not further empty the villages: the rural Workers' Cooperative, either as the heir/owner or as a provider of productive services to the large rural co-ops.

item.title: How prejudices about social organization and the sexual division of labor give us a distorted view of the past
item.description:
Systematic and genetic studies of Mesolithic and Neolithic burials show that the type of work tools buried with the deceased was not divided by sex or status:

“Many of the burials with the most numerous lithic finds at Zvejnieki are of women and/or young individuals (toddlers, older children, young adults). This effectively challenges persistent “one man fits one tool” narratives within Stone Age funerary studies. At Zvejnieki, issues of gender bias may also have skewed the dataset, as certain lithic objects, particularly bifacial points, are described as “a characteristic form of male grave goods, although also found in the graves of children and adolescents.” Despite the possibility of gender bias, our results, which incorporate the latest ancient DNA sexing data, show that the percentage of female burials with lithic objects in primary contexts is virtually the same as that of males.”

item.title: The atomization and closure of bars
item.description:
In Great Britain, traditional pubs—a neighborhood "living room" where you could eat a few things, drink a lot, talk more, watch football matches, and occasionally gather the neighborhood—have been in decline since the beginning of the century and plummeting since the pandemic. The result: loneliness, fragmentation, and a loss of community cohesion in working-class neighborhoods. In contrast, in the city center and wealthier areas, the number of restaurants remains fairly stable.

"The decline of pubs and bars has long concerned activists who see them as vital community spaces. The new research underscores how closures are reshaping neighborhoods, especially in deprived areas where pubs once provided affordable social outlets."

item.title: Europe is open source (and free)
item.description:
"The incorporation of open source software (OSS) into workflows and infrastructure is increasingly common in organizations across Europe. The report indicates that 64% use OSS for their operating systems, 55% for cloud and container technologies, and 54% for web and application development."

«The reason for OSS’s popularity is clear, as the report suggests: by using it, respondents reported benefiting from increased productivity (63%), higher-quality software (75%), reduced vendor lock-in (62%), and lower software ownership costs (58%). Furthermore, OSS was seen as a gateway to greater transparency (49%), innovation (58%), and cross-border collaboration (48%). Overall, 56% of respondents believe the benefits of OSS outweigh, or significantly outweigh, the costs.»

item.title: When a Work Cooperative is the heir to a prosperous business
item.description:
Les Établissements Fauroux was founded more than 80 years ago by Robert Fauroux. In 1964, Pierre joined the company with his father. He later became its manager. Meanwhile, the workshop diversified and began offering school transport in 1966 (the first school service in the Tarn). The workshop moved from Place aux Arcades to its current location in 1974. Jean-François arrived in 1991, before taking over management alone in 2000.

Today, the company operates in a variety of industries: automotive (Renault agent), passenger transport and travel agency (voyagerfauroux), recreational gardening (Fauroux motoculture), and bicycles (Les Vélos de Léonce).
With more than 40 employees, it is recognized for its expertise and local customer service. It is also a key player in the local economy. Since July 4, the Fauroux company has transformed into a Workers' Cooperative.

item.title: Responses to Mamdani
item.description:
New York, USA, has no supermarkets or markets in working-class neighborhoods. But if the market doesn't attract businesses, the solution isn't necessarily to nationalize food distribution.

«When Democratic mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani recently proposed that New York City spend $60 million to open government-run grocery stores to address food deserts, he put his finger on a very real problem: too many New Yorkers lack access to affordable, nutritious food.

But too often, the left favors strategies focused on large-scale, centralized government solutions, while the right looks solely to the private sector. This excludes a number of proven approaches that already exist in our neighborhoods. Instead of creating a new bureaucracy, New York should invest in food co-ops: community-rooted institutions that have worked here before and could work again.

item.title: What happened after the legalization of the Work Cooperative in South Korea in 2011?
item.description:
Following the passage of the FAC, other cooperative initiatives were undertaken. For example, the Happy Bridge cooperative operates a successful restaurant franchise, Guksu Namu ("Noodle Tree"), with over 600 locations in Korea. The company's five founders were progressive social activists long committed to workplace democracy. They sought alternative forms of social enterprise for their restaurant and traveled to Italy and Spain to learn about Mondragón, a successful federation of worker cooperatives based in Spain. In March 2013, shortly after the FAC went into effect, the Happy Bridge founders transformed their business into a worker cooperative. By 2020, Happy Bridge had 96 worker-owners, six pre-worker-owners, and 15 employees, generating revenues exceeding $50 million.

As of February 2023, there were more than 693 worker cooperatives in Korea. Compared to other cooperative sectors, such as consumer cooperatives or social cooperatives, the cooperative movement has grown slowly. Gangtae Park, leader of the Workers' Cooperative Association, points out that Korea's capitalist economy is deeply suspicious of any worker organization. 6 Changing mindsets so that people are open to creating an economy that prioritizes collaboration among workers has been a challenge.

item.title: How a Worker Cooperative helped overcome overexploitation in the textile industry in Thailand
item.description:
The founders, like other rural migrants who had moved to the cities at the time, joined one of the many textile and garment factories operating in the country. The terrible conditions—long hours, low wages, and an authoritarian environment—are, thankfully, a thing of the past for Kaewpaka. Today, he and 14 other workers from that factory have created their own worker-run textile cooperative, Dignity Returns, and successfully run a "horizontal" model based on their own principles of decent work.

The group formed 15 years ago, after the textile factory they worked at closed unexpectedly. Despite the conditions, Kaewpaka says he wasn't at all happy about its closure. Once again, economic necessity was determining his life choices. He and the factory's 700 workers demanded the week's wages the company hadn't paid them before closing, as well as severance pay. For three months, the group protested in front of the Ministry of Labor, setting up sewing machines on stairwells and attracting media attention. The three-month struggle further united the small group of workers and eventually led to the founding of Dignity Returns.

"The demonstrations stopped, but in the end we remained deeply united by friendship and solidarity," says Kaewpaka.

item.title: Gawker Media's Cooperative Successors
item.description:
The creators of "Defector," former employees of the closed "Deadspin" (USA), value their experience as a Work Cooperative after five years in the market and the validity and sustainability of the model for other journalists.

«The employee-ownership model can work in any context. It just depends on what those implementing it consider successful. Honestly, we set the bar very high because, when we launched, we had 19 people. That's a lot of people to feed and make money so they can live. And we achieved it. But many sites have already done something similar to ours, but with five or ten people, and that's much more feasible in terms of the number of subscribers needed to make it worthwhile. So I think it's definitely replicable.

In the era of newsletters, especially with Substack, it's hard to convince some people that it would be better to start a co-op with others rather than go it alone. Because if you join Substack and get a significant number of subscribers, you can make a lot of money.

So I think that's an impediment to this kind of business model. But I think there's real value in not being alone, having people to work with, edit, bounce ideas off of, and just create a publication. I think a publication has things to offer that an individual newsletter writer can't.
Deadspin

item.title: The need for an antagonist in the discourse of the new Zeitgeist
item.description:
"Parties that promise to reduce inequalities without resorting to the antinomy between producer and parasite fail to mobilize," notes Esteban Hernández.

"The tension, central to our time, between the productive and financial economies has been well understood by the populist right and even less so by Vox; the left hasn't grasped it at all. And yet, it's a scenario that could pave the way for progressive forces."

It could, yes, if the parasitic monster that the University has become, the Dutch consulting firms at the #EU gatherings, the endless university observatories and diagnoses, the supposedly "participatory" structures and expert groups were not identified as being at the forefront of "parasites" at a time when public funds are scarce and public services are being cut and degenerated throughout Europe.

The European far right is playing this card to the fullest, attacking, for example, the Leader funds and proposing to give the money directly to farmers. Local development groups have long ceased to inspire hope. They are associated with bureaucracy, difficulties, and projects that are not guided by perceived local needs but by urban trends. The endless organic farming courses where not a single farmer attends have ended up generating rejection.

item.title: New distributed sensors created that are independent of batteries or solar panels
item.description:
To monitor agriculture efficiently and intelligently, we need sensors—for example—that can record the amount of chemicals in runoff water to determine the necessary dosages for fertilizers and other treatments. However, sensors require an external power source, either a battery or a solar panel, which complicates their operation and limits their deployment.

Now, thanks to the relationship between chemistry and light, compounds in water can be detected using so little energy that it can be obtained from the flow of water through the sensor, making the sensors independent of an external source of electricity and freeing them from many of their limitations.

item.title: An alternative to the concentration of healthcare in large private hospital groups
item.description:
In the US, traditional clinics are closing, and primary care physicians are becoming employees of large hospital groups that are buying up old local clinics.

And yet, along comes Meroka, a medical technology startup whose business is “turning physician-owned clinics into employee-owned practices with a modern service portfolio.”

The first cohort includes five obstetrics and gynecology practices in five states. They are small by corporate standards (3 to 8 physicians, 15 to 80 employees, $3 to $10 million in annual gross revenue or collections), but with an outsized community impact (often more than 100 patients per day, 15,000 to 20,000 patients per year).

According to Meroka, early results show an approximate 5% increase in revenue over the six months, driven by higher collections, fewer denials, and targeted cost reductions, such as malpractice premiums.

item.title: The Duralex epic told from the manager's perspective
item.description:
«On August 1, 2024, we officially became a cooperative. That day, I visited the factory to congratulate the teams. I arrived at a very dark area and was shocked, and they told me, "From now on, it's our money, let's be careful." Usually, in the screw warehouse, workers would take batches; here, they ordered two, which was exactly what they needed. This resulted in immediate savings on consumables and energy—up to 10%!

The culture of mutual support is also gaining ground. Being a partner employee significantly influences the internal culture and the enjoyment of working together.

We've installed screens in the factory, where we communicate the week's figures and key information: our presence at a stand, a transaction with a specific distributor. Communication has become more intensive and effective: information and strategy are no longer reserved for private purposes, making working relationships more horizontal and highly motivating.

Finally, what we're doing is historic: there's no heavy industry of our size with our legal form. Employees understand this perfectly. So much so that Harvard, Essec, and the Sorbonne sent three researchers to describe our model and teach it to their students. There, we're doing everything we can to ensure the next 80 years of Duralex, which belongs above all to the French.

item.description:
A Maple Ridge-based company has made business history by becoming Canada's largest employee-owned trust and the first in the social services sector.

Taproot Community Support Services, with 750 employees in British Columbia, Alberta, and a small number in Ontario, announced this week that an Employee Ownership Trust (EOT) has acquired a majority stake in the company. All employees hold equal shares in the company.

Taproot is the largest company to become EOT-owned since the federal government introduced this ownership model in 2024.

item.title: Traditional Housing Cooperative to reduce property costs
item.description: "At a critical time for access to housing in the Canary Islands, the cooperative approach to building houses is consolidating as a key player in the solution to the housing crisis. The severe shortage of new homes, coupled with a structural mismatch between supply and demand—with more than 11,000 homes in demand in the Canary Islands annually compared to a supply of barely 3,000 units—has created a massive housing gap. The situation is exacerbated by rising construction costs, a shortage of labor in the sector, and the lack of resources within local governments to expedite the licensing process, which makes the process more expensive and difficult."

item.title: Cooperativism as Self-Defense: Cooperativism and the Struggle for Equality among Acadians, French-Speakers in Northern Canada
item.description:
Cooperatives are often formed to serve marginalized communities. These organizations are jointly owned by their members, who make decisions on their policies and guidelines. Cooperatives typically operate with one vote per member and are built around a common need.

Examples of francophone cooperatives in New Brunswick range from “golden age clubs” for seniors to the Coopérative Transport Chaleur, a transport cooperative with vans and other accessible vehicles.

There are 151 cooperatives in New Brunswick, 25 of them primarily bilingual, according to figures from the New Brunswick Financial and Consumer Services Commission.

Forty-four percent of New Brunswick cooperatives are predominantly francophone, not counting those identified as bilingual. This is a high rate, considering that francophones represent only 30% of New Brunswick's population, according to the 2021 census.

item.title: Post with image
In 10 days
A work cooperative emerges to revitalize a fishing village facing depopulation.
item.description:
The Karimata cooperative, on the tropical island of Miyakojima, Japan, is celebrating its third year of operation, fighting depopulation and bringing cooperative work to where it's most needed:

Karimata is currently in decline due to the emigration of young people, a declining birth rate, and an aging population. However, the culture of cooperation has been present in this village since before. In the history of overcoming harsh climatic conditions, such as typhoons and droughts, which it has suffered on numerous occasions, mutual aid has been cultivated as a form of lifelong wisdom. Symbolic of this is the self-governing association, which has been in existence for over 120 years, and the joint purchasing store, which operates thanks to the investment of 99 local residents.

Although they cannot be converted into monetary value, there are many necessary jobs that are indispensable for living in depopulated areas. In Karimata, transporting elderly people and children, mowing the lawns in the village, and organizing local events are activities that are difficult to convert into value in a market economy and are often overlooked in today's profit-first era. Since it takes approximately half an hour by car to reach the town center, supporting residents without transportation is especially important, but the shortage of workers is becoming increasingly acute.

"In the past, we used to introduce car-sharing as a city transportation service for students and seniors, and we conducted a demonstration experiment with Okinawa Toyota. What was revealed was the high financial cost of continuing the business. Since these businesses don't generate large profits, it's difficult for large companies to acquire them. That's why I believe the perspective and power of residents can directly solve the problems facing the local community."

In addition, they are renovating old private homes that are now empty and preparing housing and accommodations managed by the Cooperative Association. Companies associated with the Karimata area are participating in the renovation work, and local projects are creating jobs and economic circulation.

"Our work is nothing new. The lifestyle and local economic structure that the people of Karimata have long woven will be passed on to the next generation. That is our role."

item.title: From consumption stratification to the income gap
item.description:
Disney as a symbol of the end of social cohesion resulting from the devaluation of work since the 1990s.

Disney's philosophy began to shift in the 1990s, with the rise of its luxury offerings, but only after the economic impact of the pandemic did the company seem to fully abandon any pretense of being a middle-class institution. Today, a Disney vacation is "for the top 20% of American households—actually, to be honest, maybe the top 10% or 5%," said Len Testa, a computer scientist whose "Unofficial Guide" books and Touring Plans website offer advice on managing crowds and minimizing lines. "Disney positions itself as the ideal American vacation. The irony is that most Americans can't afford it."
